Build ID: v200705080500

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Import sample project
2. Close sample project
3. Restart application
4. Open sample project
5. Open Language Mappings property page
6. Click Apply
7. An exception is thrown (see below)

If I close and reopen the project between step 4 and 5, then the exception is not thrown.

Note that I cannot reproduce this with normal CDT projects.


More information:
The following exception is thrown:

Just found, that setReadOnly is not yet called when the exception occurs. Must be something else then.
Created an attachment (id=66277)
Stacktrace saving language mapping

The CConfigurationSpecSettings setting has a readonly storage base in CConfigBasedDescriptorManager.reconsile line: 550, and finally an exception is thrown in CStorage.importStorage(String, ICStorageElement) line: 93.
It seems that accessing a project description too early causes this issue. A resource change listener accesses a project description while the main thread is initializing a project description for the very same project.

When I suspend the separate thread accessing the project description, and resume it when the main thread has finished its job, then everything works fine. However, using a job with workspace scheduling rule does not help.

I have no idea how I can check when I can use a project description.

Any ideas?

Thanks,

    Gerhard
I'll have a look
Created an attachment (id=66334)
The stacktrace of the main thread

Thanks Mikhail!

BTW, this is the stacktrace where a simultaneous access to a project description causes this issue. If the other thread is suspended until the main thread finishes project description loading (see this stacktrace), everything is fine, and no exception is thrown.
FYI:
Putting the body of the method

public ICProjectDescription CProjectDescriptionManager.getProjectDescription(IProject project, boolean load, boolean write)

into a synchronized(project) block solves the problem, but it seems to block the GUI a little bit upon application start.

Best regards,

   Gerhard
Created an attachment (id=66512)
Patch by Anton Leherbauer

Created an attachment (id=66515)
Another patch for the same issue (by me)

The latest patch synchronized access to the project description (in order to avoid multiple threads running into loadProjectDescription at the same time).

Both patches separately fix this issue. However, it may by reasonable to apply both.
Created an attachment (id=66639)
JUnit test case which reveals the exception

I have now a better understanding of what's going on:
When two threads try to get the ICDescriptor for the same project and the CProjectDescription object is not yet loaded (can only happen by recursion), each thread gets a different instance because of ThreadLocal storage of CProjectDescription objects in the loading state. When loading completes, the CProjectDescription is stored in a non-ThreadLocal way, ie. all threads will get the same object, which is fine. The problem is that each CProjectDescription object will be stored this way, i.e. only the object of the last thread will actually survive, but an event about this is sent only the first time. This event is handled by the CConfigBasedDecriptorManager to update ICDescriptors accordingly. Thus the ICProjectDescriptor associated to the last CProjectDescriptor object will never be updated.

The provided test case causes an IllegalWriteAccess exception quite reliably (although it is not guaranteed to  do so).
(In reply to comment #11)
Thanks Anton,

I'm currently working on fixing this issue and should have a solution for this soon. I'll make sure the test-case passes before making the check-in.

Thanks,
Mikhail
I've checked in a fix that should solve the issue. The test-case provided by Anton is always passing for me now. I've checked in the test-case as well since, but made it to be the last in the list of CDescriptorTests since otherwise the test-case caused failures of other test-cases in CDescriptorTests, because the CDescriptorTests test-cases seem to somehow depend on the project data set-up in previous test-cases.

NOTE: among other fixes I've made the ICDescriptorManager.getDescriptor() methods to be synchronized since this is how it was in the 3.x

Please verify and re-open if needed

Mikhail
Thanks Mikhail!

I can confirm that your patch works.

Gerhard

This can happen if there are 2 instances of CConfigBasedDescriptorManager.
CConfigBasedDescriptorManager.getInstance() is not thread-safe.
(In reply to comment #16)
> This can happen if there are 2 instances of CConfigBasedDescriptorManager.
> CConfigBasedDescriptorManager.getInstance() is not thread-safe.
OK, I'll make sure getInstance() for all managers are thread safe and post a notification here once I'm done. And we'll see if this fixes the problem

Mikhail


Making CProjectDescriptionManager.getInstance and CConfigBasedDescriptorManager.getInstance synchronized did not fix the problem. 

I reverted the bugfix for bug #186755 on my machine, and the exception does not occur anymore.

However, I think it is reasonable to make manager methods synchronized.
(In reply to comment #18)
> Making CProjectDescriptionManager.getInstance and
